name: English Opening
description: A flexible opening where White controls the center from the flank. Can transpose into many different positions.

move.explanation: Welcome to the English Opening! Instead of charging straight into the center, you stake a claim on the d5 square from the side — like sneaking around to control the playground without starting a fight.
Black plants a pawn right in the center, claiming space and daring White to challenge it.
Develop the queen's knight toward the center. It puts pressure on d5 and e4 and helps control the important central squares.
Black develops the knight to a great central square, attacking the c4 pawn and preparing to castle.
Develop your king's knight to its ideal square. It eyes the e5 pawn and prepares to fianchetto your bishop with g3.
Black develops the other knight, defending e5 and fighting for the center. Now both sides have two knights out — great development!
Prepare to fianchetto your bishop on g2. This bishop will be a powerful long-range piece, controlling the center from the side.
Black pins your c3 knight, preventing it from capturing the e5 pawn. This is an aggressive and principled response.
Complete the fianchetto! Your bishop on g2 is a mighty piece that controls the whole long diagonal from g2 to a8.
Black castles to safety. Both sides are developing smoothly — the game is evenly balanced.
Castle! Your king is safe and your rook joins the game. Now you can focus on the center with moves like d3 and a3.
Black pushes the pawn forward aggressively, trying to cramp White's position. Now Ng5 or Ne1 followed by d3 will dissolve the pawn.
Black mirrors your move! This creates a symmetrical position — both sides fight for the same squares.
Develop the knight toward the center. In symmetrical positions, good development is the key to getting an advantage.
Black mirrors again with the queen's knight. This pure symmetry is a hallmark of the Symmetrical English.
Break the symmetry by starting the fianchetto. You aim to get the bishop on g2 and then castle, reaching a very comfortable setup.
Black also fianchettos! Now both sides will have bishops pointing toward the middle — a fascinating battle of long diagonals.
Place the bishop on g2 — the best diagonal in the English Opening. It reaches all the way to a8 and controls many important squares.
Black completes the fianchetto too. The g7 bishop will fight hard against your g2 bishop for control of the long diagonal.
Develop the king's knight and prepare to castle. You have a well-coordinated setup ready for the middlegame.
Black plays the Slav setup, preparing to support a d5 pawn advance. This is a very solid and careful choice.
Develop the knight and wait to see what Black does. The English is very flexible — you can decide your setup based on Black's choices.
Black advances the d-pawn as planned. Now the c4 pawn and the d5 pawn are in direct contact.
Exchange in the center. This opens the position slightly and forces Black to decide how to recapture.
Black recaptures with the c-pawn, keeping a strong pawn center. The position now resembles a Panov Attack from the Caro-Kann.
Establish a strong pawn center with d4 and e-pawn later. Now you have space and active play ahead.
Black develops actively, attacking the d4 pawn. Both sides are racing to complete development.
Develop the knight and support the d4 pawn. The position is balanced with rich play ahead for both sides.
Black plays a cautious move, supporting a future d5 and keeping the position solid. This often leads to Queen's Gambit-style positions.
Develop the knight toward the center. The English is very flexible — you can adopt a fianchetto setup regardless of what Black does.
Black occupies the center with two pawns. This is a very classical, solid approach.
Begin the fianchetto — this will transpose into a Catalan-style position, one of White's most powerful setups against d5 and e6.
Black develops the knight to a great central square. Both sides are building up their positions carefully.
Complete the fianchetto! The g2 bishop will apply long-term pressure on the d5 pawn and the queenside.
Black develops the bishop safely to e7, preparing to castle. This solid approach is very popular at all levels.
Castle and reach the standard Catalan setup. Your bishop on g2 will squeeze Black's position for the whole game.

plan.summary: Control the center indirectly with 1.c4, develop knights and fianchetto the king's bishop on g2, then castle and apply long-term pressure with the powerful g2 bishop. Stay flexible — the English can adapt to almost any Black response.

strategicGoals.description: Control d5 and e4 from the flank with c4 and the knights
Fianchetto the king's bishop on g2 to dominate the long diagonal
Castle kingside early for king safety
Squeeze Black's position with long-term positional pressure

plan.pawnStructureTarget: c4 flank control with flexible d3/d4 options

pieceTargets.reasoning: The fianchettoed bishop controls the long a8-g2 diagonal, pressuring the queenside and center for many moves
Controls d5 and supports the c4 pawn — the engine of the English Opening
Fights for e5 and d4, supports a future d4 push and defends the kingside after castling

typicalPlans: Fianchetto the bishop (g3, Bg2) and castle, then apply positional pressure
Play d3 and Nbd2 to support a later e4 push in the center
In the Symmetrical English, try to be the first to break symmetry with a well-timed d4
commonMistakes: Rushing d4 without the bishop on g2 to support it
Playing Nc3 and then blocking the c-pawn's advance — coordinate your pieces first
Forgetting that the English is patient — don't attack prematurely before development is complete
plan.historicalNote: The English Opening is named after Howard Staunton, the leading English player who popularized it in the 1840s. It became a favorite of world champions Mikhail Botvinnik, Anatoly Karpov, and Garry Kasparov, who used it to steer the game into strategic battles they controlled.

planLessons.title: The Idea of 1.c4
planLessons.description: Instead of fighting for the center with a pawn on e4 or d4, White controls the important d5 square from the side. It's like guarding the middle of the playground from the edge — sneaky and effective!

planLessons.title: The Powerful Fianchetto Bishop
planLessons.description: After g3 and Bg2, your bishop becomes a long-range sniper on the g2-a8 diagonal. It controls many squares without even moving — patient and powerful!

planLessons.title: The Symmetrical English Trap
planLessons.description: When Black copies every move (c5, Nc6, g6...), you must break symmetry first. Playing d4 at the right moment gives you the advantage — Black's copy-cat strategy will fall apart.

planLessons.title: Castle Before Attacking
planLessons.description: Get your king to safety on g1 before pushing pawns or attacking. The English is a long-game opening — patience and safety first!

planLessons.title: Don't Rush d4 Too Early
planLessons.description: Jumping to d4 before developing your pieces can backfire. Here Black has a solid position and your pawn center becomes a target. Develop first!

planQuizzes.prompt: You played 1.c4 and Black responded 1...e5. What is your best next move?

choices.text: Nc3 — develop the knight and pressure d5 and e4

planQuizzes.explanation: Nc3 is the right idea — develop pieces toward the center. The queen's knight belongs on c3 where it fights for the key squares. The other moves waste time or put pieces on bad squares.

planQuizzes.prompt: White has played g3. What is the best square for the bishop?

choices.text: g2 — fianchetto! The best square in the English

planQuizzes.explanation: Bg2 completes the fianchetto! The bishop on g2 is a powerhouse in the English Opening, controlling the long diagonal and putting pressure on Black's position for the entire game.

planQuizzes.prompt: It's Black's turn. Black copies with ...g6. What should White do next?

choices.text: Bg2 — complete the fianchetto and keep building
d4 — immediately break the symmetry with a pawn push
h4 — attack on the kingside right away

planQuizzes.explanation: Complete your development first with Bg2 before doing anything aggressive. In the English Opening, finishing your setup calmly puts you in an excellent position for the middlegame.

theoryLessons.title: Four Knights English (A28)
theoryLessons.description: After 1.c4 e5 2.Nc3 Nf6 3.Nf3 Nc6, all four knights are developed. This is one of the most classical English positions, rich with strategic ideas and transpositional possibilities.

theoryLessons.title: Symmetrical English (A30)
theoryLessons.description: After 1.c4 c5, both sides fight for the same squares with mirror symmetry. White must break the symmetry at the right moment — usually with d4 — to claim an advantage.

theoryLessons.title: Anglo-Slav / Anglo-Indian (A11)
theoryLessons.description: After 1.c4 c6, Black prepares a Slav Defense setup. White responds with Nf3 and g3, reaching a flexible position that can transpose into the Catalan or Reti.

theoryLessons.title: The Bb4 Pin in the Four Knights
theoryLessons.description: When Black plays ...Bb4, pinning your Nc3, the correct response is Bg2 — complete your development. The pin is not dangerous because your g2 bishop will be so strong that the knight's loss would be compensated.

theoryQuizzes.prompt: This Four Knights English position is reached after 1.c4 e5 2.Nc3 Nf6 3.Nf3 Nc6. What is White's best next move?

choices.text: e4 — grab the center with a pawn

theoryQuizzes.explanation: g3 begins the fianchetto, which is White's most thematic plan in the English Opening. After Bg2 and O-O, the bishop on g2 will control the board for many moves.

theoryQuizzes.prompt: Black has played 1...c5, copying your move. This variation is called the...?
theoryQuizzes.explanation: When Black mirrors 1.c4 with 1...c5, it's the Symmetrical English (ECO A30). Both pawns fight for the same squares, and White must break the symmetry at the right time — usually with d4.

move.explanation: Black stakes out the center with the king's pawn, fighting for space immediately.

responses.name: Reversed Sicilian / King's English
responses.description: Black occupies the center with e5, leading to the King's English. This is the most classical and fighting response.
responses.planAdjustment: Play Nc3, Nf3, g3, Bg2, and O-O. The four knights setup with the fianchetto is your most reliable plan against e5.

move.explanation: Black mirrors your move, creating the Symmetrical English where both sides fight for the same central squares.

responses.name: Symmetrical English
responses.description: Black mirrors 1.c4 with 1...c5, creating a symmetrical battle. White must break symmetry at the right time.
responses.planAdjustment: Play Nc3, g3, Bg2, Nf3, and O-O. Look for the right moment to play d4 and break the symmetry — that's when you gain an edge.

move.explanation: Black develops the knight immediately, keeping options open. This flexible move delays revealing Black's pawn structure.

responses.name: Anglo-Indian Defense
responses.description: Black plays Nf6 without committing pawns, leading to an Anglo-Indian structure with many transpositional options.
responses.planAdjustment: Play Nc3, g3, Bg2, Nf3, O-O, and then decide between d4 (Catalan-style) or d3 (King's Indian Attack-style) based on how Black sets up.

move.explanation: Black plays a cautious, solid move preparing d5. This often leads to Queen's Gambit or Catalan-style positions.

responses.name: English: ...e6 System
responses.description: Black sets up a solid structure with e6 and d5, similar to the Queen's Gambit Declined. Transposes well into Catalan.
responses.planAdjustment: Respond with Nf3, g3, Bg2, and O-O — you'll reach a Catalan-like position where the g2 bishop slowly squeezes Black's queenside.
